text: all right hi everyone big thingy v tano
here the internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review of the new
nas album kings disease 2. this is a new
lp from legendary queens new york rapper
nas coming back a quick year after the
release of the grammy-winning king's
disease a momentous moment in naza's
catalog not just because of the great
hit boy production on every single track
but the history and sage-like
perspective he was able to lace into
much of this record too it's a good
project but i was kind of skeptical
seeing we were going to get a sequel in
such a short amount of time would king's
disease 2 just be more of the same
leftovers or something like that but
actually king's disease too is really
its own animal or maybe even the other
side of the same coin as lyrically here
nas is addressing a lot of the same
themes be it personal and hip-hop
history his luxurious lifestyle some
social commentary as well there's a lot
of bases getting touched here but the
attitude and the delivery this time
around is a lot meaner and more direct
because i think king's disease too more
than kings disease one is about showing
the voice the flow the lyrical artistry
and competitive spirit that made nas a
rap legend to begin with here king's
disease one is kind of like the ice and
king's disease too is the fire and yes
we have another full run of hit boy
production on this record too the dreamy
opener pressure describes a lot of
what's motivating the creative process
behind this record nas describing the
weight of the world on his shoulders the
need to inspire them again and cynically
you could see this as a nas i don't know
showing his god complex a little bit is
the world really on his shoulders even
in a figurative sense no and of course
nas is a flawed human being like the
rest of us but as a master of his craft
and a leader in hip-hop that's where his
words are going to resonate the deepest
and he's definitely earned that mic in
that podium and i say podium very
purposefully because nas also isn't just
here to spit but at least uh you know in
his own explanation here to bestow
perspective for example the track death
row east is a history lesson a trip down
memory lane during a pivotal moment for
rap music nas essentially reminiscing
about a time when death row records was
flirting with the idea of building out
an east coast branch and death row was a
massive cultural force at the time if
this had gone through it would have
changed everything but the death of
tupac and the crumbling of the label
obviously forced things into a different
direction and nas is essentially
explaining his own proximity to all of
this and just kind of telling it through
his own eyes on the following 40 side we
have things shifting to current day at
least sonically hit boy brings a smooth
and moody trap b on this one and nas is
just casually sounding amazing on it
aesthetically this instrumental hits
upon a pretty trendy sound right now
it's the type of vibe that you could see
drake rapping over but you can't deny
that nas like really does his own thing
with it then we have the explosive epmd2
a new version of a song that was
originally on the judas and the black
messiah soundtrack on this latest
edition we have new bars from nas an
epmd feature even an m m feature on the
back end where he goes like at length
with a nasty beat switch normally i'd be
against an artist of naza's caliber
recycling a song like this for a core
record but
he really beefed up this new version pmd
and eric sermon in their sections of the
track still have godlike chemistry and
the rap god uh didn't really get on my
nerves in the ways that he typically
does save for a couple of bars
bucks flying when i make it rain
deer
again shady's uh flow switch on the back
end of the track with that beat switch
was absolutely sick and dizzying and
again i love that nas and hit boy
renovated this song and made it exciting
to listen to again then the track rare
was another highlight for me i love the
warmth coming off the speed the
nostalgia nasa's lyrics and delivery
sounds like he's soaring through space
just high off his own success it's
blissful it's okay but it turns out this
section of the track is just a warm up
for what's to come in the second half of
the track we get a cipher worthy beat
switch a more intense flow from nas and
from there there's so many sharp bars
and even song ideas flying at me at a
million miles an hour this gangsta
refrain that he harps on toward the very
end of the track that could be a hook
for an entirely different song in and of
itself i love that nas and hit boy on
this record are
digging out so much gold they're just
like looking for songs and passages just
to just throw it in yktv or you know the
vibe was a track i was a little
skeptical about given just how modern
the production is and on the features we
have a boogie with the hoodie and yg
which like those names plus nas just in
concept doesn't necessarily come off as
like complimentary vibes but oddly
enough this track is still a banger and
lyrically there's a point where nas even
i guess acknowledges this uh clashing of
worlds and aesthetics here mentioning uh
uzi over a primo beat an nas over amigo
beat overall naz's performance on this
track is pretty cold-blooded much like
in a lot of other pockets here it's
highly enjoyable boogie is providing a
really smooth melodic midpoint for the
track and yg comes off a little more
animated than usual i love this a drop
of cardo on your head act stupid with it
line and delivery that he has going on
where he's really just like messing with
his inflections in a crazy way store run
is another retrospective moment on this
lp where nas is going into the past the
present the past the present against fat
kicks and classy soul samples he's
rapping about his era his pedigree the
luxury that has come with his success
and how that contrasts from
the shootouts and razor blades that
paint his past nobody with lauren hill
is a different reflection on fame on
this record as with this track naz seeks
to escape from it looking for a place
where he can kind of be a nobody on
nasa's part lyrically the track is
cleverly written it's focused and i love
that lauren hill is not only sounding
great too but she is
backing up the themes and just the basic
vibe of this track too uh with her own
feelings on fame and her perception
within the public eye and given her
elusive past i think she's like the
perfect addition for this kind of track
we continue on this more introspective
and sensitive kick with the song no
phony love featuring charlie wilson now
at this point in his career nas is no
stranger to
making songs about the highs and lows of
love but i have to say i think this is
one of his best so far not just because
of the perfect instrumental setting i'm
loving the romantic r b loops worked
into this beat on this one from hit boy
but charlie wilson's vocals are
fantastic and a necessary touch plus i
like the tone of nas's lyrics quite a
bit on this one too with one bar after
another nas hits us with these potent
jabs of lust insecurity fear and uh
infatuation i mean everything that love
can entail no phone in love if only love
so good brunch on sundays is maybe my
least favorite cut off of the record
mostly because of the weak hook some of
the bars from nas unfortunately weren't
a bit of an eye roll the sunday fun day
hashtag line i thought was a little
under
his uh i guess ability but given the
general themes of the record the sunday
to sunday line as well i get the
celebratory tone of the track i get why
nas would want to switch up to that at
this point on the record i just don't
think it's one of his best songs here
count me in i thought was a bit of a
mild one in the track list i'm feeling
nas's lyrics a lot more than i am the
production which is very uh low-key or
the spaced out chorus that i don't think
has a lot of punch to it hit boy helps
himself to a featured verse on the front
end of the song composure with a sort of
currency type flow on this one hit boy's
feature is fine nas on the track is fine
as well but i feel like this song's
themed composure being able to handle
yourself is already a pretty consistent
theme throughout this lp and i don't
think the song scratches into the idea
any more deeply than much of the other
material here i think the spoken word
outro actually brings the message home
better than much of the wrapping on the
track the following my bible was another
highlight in the track list for me i
will say that the gender politics on
this one are a little dated but the
instrumental on this one is great it's
super classy i think nasa's conceptual
structuring of this track is great too
and his biblical portrayals of men and
women i think are more well-intentioned
than uh some artists have been who have
done something similar in the past we
then have the assuring closer nas is
good which doesn't necessarily bring
anything to
a head or put a stamp on much of
anything but i do think it ends the
whole king's disease the series on a
positive note showing nas is kind of
proving his worth here just depicting
himself in a good place and i suppose
this is where he's gonna leave us unless
uh him and hit boy decide to treat us to
a third uh king this disease which uh
given the quality of this i wouldn't
necessarily mind but yeah king's disease
too i thought was a really quality
record a lot of great thoughtful tracks
from nas a fantastic production from
hitboy i think they went a little bit
harder than they did on the original
kings disease and
the results show it and i think we can
leave it there i'm feeling a light too
decent eight on this one tran position
have you given this album a listen did
you love it did you hate it what would
you rate it you're the best you're the
best what should i review next hit the
like if you like please subscribe please
don't cry hit the bell as well over here
next to my head it's another video that
you can check out hit that up or the
link to subscribe to the channel anthony
fantano nas kings disease 2 forever
